posts.name: Brock
posts.cooked: Currently our team is using Autodesk Fusion to CAD and machine our robot, but I’ve heard that many of the other FRC teams use OnShape, so I’m wondering what people like about each of them and what anyone reading would recommend.  With the offseason coming up soon, I’d like to get this figured out so we can get everyone properly trained without having to switch midway through the offseason. Thanks!

posts.name: jedgar6
posts.cooked: Yes. (Onshape)

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked:
I was an intermediate or better Fusion user, and the school teaches some classes in Fusion (though not super deep classes).

I looked at the FRC landscape and concluded that onshape was better for both within-team multiplayer access/commenting, etc. and for having a richer set of CAD from other teams to reference/use.

They’re both parametric CAD systems, so if you’re very good with one, the other is a matter of picking up the UI gestures, but the fundamental approach is going to feel very familiar.

We went with onshape this year (against the desires of a few vocal members) and it went fine. Even the vocal ones came around to being at least OK with onshape.

posts.name: Zakk Jackson
posts.cooked: Onshape, because there is more FRC support for it.

posts.name: Monica
posts.cooked: One thing I really like about Onshape is the ability to use it on almost any device with an internet connection. Being able to quickly look up a dimension or assembly detail on your phone is pretty great.

posts.name: ehochstein
posts.cooked: I highly recommend using Onshape in conjunction with https://www.frcdesign.org/ .

As a former Fusion purist turned Onshape user, Onshape is miles better than Fusion for FRC purposes. Fusion does have the built in CAM software but I think generally Onshape is much better for an FRC environment.

posts.name: JohnD 3322
posts.cooked:
DaiTou567:

Onshape is miles better than Fusion for FRC purposes. Fusion does have the built in CAM software but I think generally Onshape is much better for an FRC environment.

Please give details on why OnShape is so much better.  We do a lot of CNC work so I’m looking for justification to give up the built in CAM software.

As previously mentioned, there’s a lot of support from the FRC community for Onshape, specifically the great learning resource that is frcdesign.org and the multitude of featurescripts that make your life a whole lot easier. My workflow just became a whole lot better with all the quality of life improvements. The other great thing about Onshape is that the browser and cloud based nature allows for much better collaborative work.

Edit: I also should add that as a lot of our students have Chromebooks, Onshape is a far suprior software as the browser version of Fusion is practically unusable at times on a Chromebook especially. Onshape, being optimized for browers, decreases the barrier for a lot of students who are interested in CAD.

posts.name: Will Weiszhaar
posts.cooked: Why not both? We use Onshape to CAD the parts and Fusion to CAM. The pipeline is a little tricky to set up first but after that it is smooth sailing.

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked: has anyone worked with the new onshape CAM?  Fusion CAM integration is one of the reasons we use it.

posts.name: Will C
posts.cooked:
If you take the time to learn Onshape and how to structure your documents before the season starts, then Onshape is 10000000% better.

Id recommend going through this cad class. It teaches you the basics of onshape and focuses on frc use cases.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: 3176 Risk Mitigation Specialist + 3D Printing Lead + Fabrication and Design

posts.cooked: Haven’t gotten our hands on it yet as access for EDU accounts comes out in the fall. Looks pretty promising but a bit unneccesary for us as we have a Carbide Create Pro license.

posts.name: Jonathan Mi
posts.cooked: I see your team is registered for champs–I’d highly recommend you attend the FRCDesign workshop on Friday .

posts.name: Benjamen Johnson
posts.cooked: I’m not sure what you mean by the pipeline being tricky, we just export a STEP file of the part from Onshape and import it into Fusion. The only problem is when you change a part, you have to reimport it into Fusion, but we use fusion templates 90% of the time so it takes 10 seconds to setup the operations.

posts.name: Will Weiszhaar
posts.cooked: Yea I may of over exaggerated how hard it was to set up, but we had some difficulties with setting up templates.

posts.name: Jake Schuler
posts.cooked: My team uses Onshape and it’s been great other than the fact that there is no offline support (meaning we can’t have a external pit display showing cad without internet) it’s been great, we are able to easily share our cad across all of our devices and any web enabled device can access it which is good since we use chromeboxes for our big displays at home.

posts.name: Alex Weiss
posts.cooked: My team used Fusion 360 and it worked very well as we did all the CAM in house. Fusion 360 CAM worked very well with our Router and Mill. Neither machine had built in CAM. If everything is in fusion you can quickly edit a part without having to switch software’s. I’ve never worked with Onshape CAM so may be ok idk. On another point, fusion does allow offline editing which was nice to be able to work on anywhere.

posts.name: RedLeader342
posts.cooked: it matters more if you have multiple cnc machines or one that doesnt have its own native cam software like carbide 3d machines do. we are the same way though. if we got a cnc mill or other machines we might go to fusion for cam.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Its BURNIE. not Bernie. And certainly not Burn-E.

posts.name: Tom
posts.cooked: We use Onshape for CAD, and have Kiri:Moto installed as an app in Onshape, which we use for CAM (and slicer for 3d printing). I’m sure it isn’t the slickest way to do CAM, but we used it for all our CNC router work this year.

data.title: Should we use Fusion or Onshape Next Season?
data.fancy_title: Should we use Fusion or Onshape Next Season?
